The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two distantly related myxozoan species. Our results show that the Myxozoa are a sister group to the cnidarian parasite Polypodium hydriforme. We also show that the Myxozoa have one of the smallest reported animal genomes. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. We found that Orf6 binds to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and disrupts its function. Our data provide a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will affect crop yields. Earlier studies suggest that once the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, mean crop yields decline and the variability of yield increases even if interannual climate variability remains unchanged. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. Herbivores are essential components of ecosystems, but their interactions with plants are often difficult to study. This is because it is difficult to identify individual plants, especially when they are abundant. We used DNA metabarcoding to identify plant species consumed by seven large mammal species in a semiarid African savanna. We found that the proportion of plant species consumed by each species varied widely, even among closely related species. These differences in diet breadth suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may be misleading when studying the interactions between large herbivores and plants. Our results highlight the importance of species-level identification of plants in studies of herbivore diets. Plastic debris is a growing problem in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may be of great importance to understand the fate of the missing plastic debris in the ocean.

Reproduction is a fundamental aspect of animal biology. However, the mechanisms that limit reproductive output are not well understood. Here, we show that the increase in reproductive output associated with domestication and allonursing is due to an increase in the mother’s metabolic power. We also show that the increase in reproductive output associated with allonursing is due to the increase in the number of offspring rather than the increase in litter size. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells. To control each function, the endothelium processes endlessly arriving requests from multiple sources using separate clusters of cells specialized to detect specific stimuli. A well-developed but poorly understood communication system operates between cells to integrate multiple lines of information and coordinate endothelial responses. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. However, the mechanisms underlying social rank establishment are largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait associated with high stress reactivity, directly influences social dominance. We further identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture multifunctional structures with desired mechanical responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed strategy can be extended to design multifunctional architectures with highly complex and navigable responses. This work provides a general framework for the design of multifunctional structures and architectures with desired behaviors. It also provides a reference for the design of function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythrocytes is regulated by the transcription factors BCL11A and GATA-1. In this study, we investigated the role of IGF2BP1, a protein that binds to mRNA, in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. We found that IGF2BP1 is downregulated in human fetal tissues and upregulated in adult tissues. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 can downregulate the expression of hemoglobin alpha and beta. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the development of hemoglobinopathies. Cancer is a major cause of death worldwide. Cancer cells are characterized by uncontrolled growth and metastasis, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. Mechanistically, this resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the transcriptional induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In conclusion, this study provides a rationale for combination of ferroptosis induction with mTORC1 inhibition in cancer therapy. Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. However, these drugs are associated with a high risk of adverse cardiovascular events. We show that calcium channel blockers promote vascular remodeling through a mechanism involving STIM/ORAI. Our findings may help to improve the safety of these drugs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for forest conservation. It was science-based, incorporated adaptive management, and was the first to require monitoring of biodiversity. We show that the NWFP has not yet achieved its goals. The policy halted clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the policy has not yet achieved its goals for early-seral ecosystems. The NWFP needs to be strengthened to achieve its conservation goals.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Therefore, the development of new antibiotics is urgently needed. Here, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the membrane permeability, solubility, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics. We show that the predicted best candidate is more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and that it is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Furthermore, the best compounds designed by us show activity against the most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Thus, the approach presented here is a promising tool for the rational design of new antibiotics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art results in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales. The resulting network is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The tropics are a critical region for the global water cycle. The transport of moisture is a key process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The record shows evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of these devices on sleep are unknown. We compared the effects of reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) with reading a printed book in the hours before bedtime. Participants reading an LE-eBook took longer to fall asleep and had reduced evening sleepiness, reduced melatonin secretion, later timing of their circadian clock, and reduced next-morning alertness than when reading a printed book. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an LE-eBook phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known climate event that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered this cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the Younger Dryas sediments is consistent with terrestrial Os. In addition, the spherules that formed at the YDB are derived from the Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that bolide impacts triggered the Younger Dryas cooling. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune tolerance. However, its specific function in different autoimmune diseases remains to be determined. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. Moreover, we show that CTLA-4 deficiency has opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance. These findings have implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals. However, the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles and to trace the evolution of genes enabling the digestion of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes enabling the digestion of plant cell walls. Our results have important implications for understanding the evolution of animal diversity and the origin of plant-feeding habits in beetles. This article is protected by copyright. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains a challenge to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm to enhance antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is the process by which cultural traits are transmitted across generations. It is a fundamental process in evolution, and is thought to be important for the emergence of complex adaptive systems. However, the extent to which larger populations enhance CCE is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE. This suggests that the extent to which larger populations enhance CCE may depend on other factors. Our results have implications for the study of CCE in general, and for the design of experiments that investigate it in particular. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the APOE4 allele. APOE is a lipid-binding protein that is highly expressed in the brain. We found that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the accumulation of complement protein C1q in the brain. These studies suggest that APOE4 may be defective in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, accelerating the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis may help to explain the increased susceptibility of APOE4 to AD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are less clear. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, marijuana abusers show reduced decreases in striatal dopamine and in the brain’s reward center. These findings suggest that chronic marijuana use is associated with decreased brain reactivity to DA stimulation. This decreased reactivity might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers. Language is the defining cognitive ability of the human species. Yet, despite its importance, the brain mechanisms of language comprehension remain mysterious. Here, we show that the most accurate artificial neural networks that predict brain activity during language processing are also the most accurate predictors of subsequent word production. These models are based on the same principles of computation and can be readily combined across different datasets and imaging modalities. They therefore provide a computational framework for understanding the brain mechanisms of language. This approach may be broadly applicable to understanding the neural basis of other cognitive and perceptual abilities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep learning is a powerful machine learning paradigm that has achieved great success in many applications. However, it is still a black box. We show that this black box can be made to solve some problems in a very precise way. We also show that this precision comes at a price.

This is based on a classic experiment published 45 years ago. However, its design flaws were not noticed at the time. This article discusses the flaws and their consequences.

Leprosy is a disease that affects humans worldwide. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis. The former causes the more common disease, leprosy, whereas the latter causes a rare disease, lepromatous leprosy. The genomes of these two species are nearly identical, but the causes of this similarity are not known. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that M. lepromatosis has lost several enzymes required for amino acid synthesis, and that M. leprae has a defective heme pathway. These differences may contribute to the pathogenesis of the two diseases. This study also provides evidence that M. lepromatosis is more closely related to the MRCA of the two species than is M. leprae. This suggests that M. lepromatosis may be a more suitable model for studying the pathogenesis of leprosy. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the keystones of quantum information theory. The interplay between them is a central topic of research. Here, we unveil the entanglement dynamics in the paradigmatic case of a quantum Heisenberg chain. We show that the entanglement dynamics is captured by a statistical ensemble with a nonzero thermodynamic entropy. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. Our result is exact and applicable to a wide class of models.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The only available vaccine is the one developed by Pfizer and BioNTech. This vaccine is effective, but it has some limitations. For example, it requires two doses, and it is not available in all countries. We describe a vaccine that is easy to produce and that can be used in mass vaccination programs. This vaccine is based on a live attenuated virus.

Plague is a disease with a long history of outbreaks and pandemics. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during the Second Pandemic is still debated. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has implications for our understanding of the history of plague and its control. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in neuroscience. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is still poorly understood. We present a comprehensive dataset of neuron numbers in amniotes, the group that includes birds and mammals. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. Our results also suggest that the evolution of brain neuronal density may be a key factor in the rise of complex cognition. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone. It is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, current inhibitors cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, the other member of the HSP90 chaperone family. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the dynamic actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in many cellular processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cell morphogenesis. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF action is still not fully understood. Here, we provide a mechanistic explanation for ADF action. We show that ADF binds to actin filaments and, upon binding, induces a mechanical torque that enhances severing. This mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding ADF function in cells and for developing new strategies to control ADF activity in vitro and in vivo. This article is protected by copyright. Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing. These findings may contribute to the development of strategies to reduce the consumption of high-calorie foods. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a rapid demographic growth. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous. This suggests that the colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia happened independently. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This is important for the interpretation of genetic studies in Madagascar. Emotional contagion is the phenomenon of people experiencing the same emotions as others. It is well established in laboratory experiments, but there is controversy about whether it occurs in the real world. We test the phenomenon in a large real-world social network. We find that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others in the real world. This work also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates them into proteins. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not only in the coding regions, but also in the noncoding regions. In this study, we found that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in the mRNA can affect the translation process. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in the regulation of protein synthesis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounders and are not driven by factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for public health and gerontology. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Ltd.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the four extant aquatic mammal lineages toward a common size attractor. This size attractor is consistent with the aquatic medium constraining the evolution of body size. This work provides a quantitative test of the energetic constraints on the evolution of body size in mammals. It also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of body size in other aquatic organisms.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically costly diseases in the world. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication suggests that the virus has evolved to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity. We show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a more efficient antiviral defense response at 37 °C than at 33 °C. This difference in the strength of the antiviral response at the two temperatures is critical for the temperature dependence of rhinovirus growth. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces. This mechanism is important for the pathogen because it allows it to regulate its virulence and biofilm formation. Our results demonstrate that pili are a mechanochemical sensor that regulates the activity of the pili. This mechanochemical model may be a general mechanism used by bacteria to sense mechanical signals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the ecological risks of these chemicals are still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation. We show that the use of pesticides is widespread and that the ecological risks are high. We also show that the use of pesticides is increasing. This study provides a basis for further research and for the development of improved pesticide regulations.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is still unclear. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. Hydropower is the leading source of renewable energy. It is also the leading cause of environmental destruction. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries. It shows that the environmental and social costs of dams are underestimated and that the benefits are overestimated. It also shows that the industry is moving toward smaller and less destructive dams.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The disease is characterized by the presence of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. The exact cause of the disease is unknown. We show that soluble amyloid β (Aβ) is toxic to neurons. We also show that Aβ causes the release of inflammatory factors from neurons. These factors are responsible for the activation of microglia, a type of brain cell, which is a major cause of the disease. This work may lead to the development of new treatments for AD. The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, its history is still largely unknown. This is a significant finding, as it provides evidence for the earliest evidence of economic exploitation of chickens in Europe. Our results also show that the domestic chicken was widely used in the Southern Levant by the end of the second millennium B.C.E. and that its use was fully established by the first century B.C.E. This is a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The folding of large proteins is a major challenge in structural biology. We have developed a method to study folding at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein. The folding is fast at high concentrations, but slow at low concentrations. The folding intermediates are heterogeneous and contain segments that are distant in the sequence. The folding pathway is not unique. The folding intermediates are important for understanding protein folding.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. Removal of these caps is critical for initiating 5′ end-dependent degradation of those RNAs, potentially affecting bacterial adaptability to stress. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon observed in nature and in many physical and biological systems. It is characterized by the fact that the system evolves toward a critical state in which the system’s activity is proportional to the available resources. The critical state is characterized by a constant activity, which is independent of the available resources. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a scaling limit of the well-known sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be transformed into a metal by applying strain. This opens up new possibilities for diamond applications.

The NCR peptides are a large group of plant antimicrobial peptides. They are highly diverse in sequence and exhibit antifungal activity in vitro and in vivo. However, the structural basis of their antifungal activity is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of one of the NCR peptides. The structure of the peptide and its mode of action against plant fungal pathogens are described. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction. We also show that the proteome of sperm is enriched with female-derived proteins immediately after mating. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets to promote blood clotting. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to VWF switches the protein to a second state with faster binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The mechanism may also be relevant to other proteins that bind to receptors on cells. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied extensively. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome. We find that the human microbiome is dominated by viruses, and that viruses are associated with many diseases.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique to observe aerosol and cloud simultaneously. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature inferred from isotopic evidence is lower than that inferred from protein reconstruction. This discrepancy has led to questions about the reliability of the isotopic evidence. Here, we present evidence that the ancestral environmental temperatures of ancient organisms reconstructed from ancestral enzymes are lower than the inferred temperatures from isotopic evidence. This finding is consistent with both isotopic and protein reconstruction-based evidence. These studies demonstrate the utility of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data to provide new insights into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are important for ion flow and cell function. Ion channels are also regulated by channel opening and closing. Ion channels commonly possess two gates, one for fast channel opening/closing and the other for slow channel inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channels show slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We propose that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world. The Plasmodium parasite infects the red blood cell (RBC) and invades the host. The invasion process is poorly understood, and the role of the RBC in the process has been largely ignored. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the RBC biophysical properties to facilitate invasion. This finding has implications for the development of new antimalarial drugs. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The seasonal outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza virus infection. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, there is no direct evidence for this process in the brain. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate the brain’s activity during the construction of syntactic structures. We found that the brain’s activity increased with each successive word in a sentence but decreased whenever words could be merged into a phrase. This decrease in activity was consistent with a bottom-up parser that applies equally to arbitrary linguistic objects. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists. They also suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are not only similar at the protein level but also genetically redundant. We show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation may be used to control the activity of the two forms of Axin in different tissues. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Obesity is a major public health problem. The mechanisms that regulate food intake are not fully understood. Here we show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces eating in sated mice. We also show that this stimulation circuit is involved in overeating. This circuit may contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth. However, the nitrogenase enzyme that fixes atmospheric nitrogen (N2) into ammonia is highly inefficient. Thus, the majority of terrestrial plants rely on a complex of bacteria and fungi, the root nodule symbiosis, to provide them with N2-fixed nitrogen. In this work, we developed a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant. This could have important implications for agriculture, where nitrogen fertilizer is the largest cost factor for cereal production. Our work also provides a platform for the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system for other organisms. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and mitigate deforestation. However, the alerts are often generated too late to deter deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities. However, the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. Animals use their hearing to detect and localize sound sources in their environment. The auditory organs of animals are all part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. The spider’s web acts as an acoustic antenna, which is able to detect and localize sound sources. The spider can also adjust and regenerate the web to meet its needs. This provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. Climate change and air pollution are the two greatest threats to human health. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use. We show that it can save 3.6 million lives per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. The chemical influence of air pollution on dust aerosols contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.5 °C globally. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.3 °C by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use is needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic with no known cure. Vaccines are the only proven intervention. However, the high cost of current vaccines may limit their global access. We engineered a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-volume microbial production. This engineered protein exhibits high-affinity binding to ACE2, and antibodies raised against it exhibit heterotypic binding to the RBD from two recently reported SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern. Presentation of the engineered RBD on a designed VLP also reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that this engineered RBD protein may be a promising candidate for a subunit vaccine. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

ALK is a receptor tyrosine kinase that is involved in the development of many tissues. In neuroblastoma, a pediatric tumor of neural crest-derived tissues, somatic ALK mutations are found. In the zebrafish, we identified a secreted ligand for ALK. Here, we show that this ligand activates ALK/LTK family receptors in vivo. Our results provide evidence that ALK/LTK family receptors are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This is of importance for the understanding of the role of ALK in neuroblastoma and other tissues. Furthermore, our results provide a tool for studying ALK/LTK family receptors in vivo. Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. The emergence of Yersinia pestis from its progenitor Yersinia pseudotuberculosis is a well-documented event, but the details of its early evolution and ecology are still largely unknown. We present 17 ancient Y. pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—is associated with men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump. This effect is not explained by political party affiliation, gender, race, or education. HM is also associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia. These findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, SOC sequestration in agricultural systems is often limited by the loss of soil organic matter (SOM) to the soil-borne mineral phase. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOM storage in agricultural systems. We also show that the benefits of these practices are highly dependent on the type of SOM and the soil-management system. Practices that increase the amount of particulate organic matter in the soil, such as incorporating legumes and applying manure, can increase the amount of SOM in the soil. Practices that increase the amount of mineral-associated organic matter, such as rotational grazing, can increase the amount of SOM in the soil. These results highlight the importance of understanding the different types of SOM and the management practices that can increase their storage. This information can be used to develop strategies for increasing SOM storage in agricultural systems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors associated with spillover and used this to rank the zoonotic potential of 887 wildlife viruses. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery projects and global surveillance. The resulting ranking of spillover potential can be used to prioritize research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This will help to inform the development of future policies and interventions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators. However, the mechanisms underlying the evolution of nectar color are not well understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this pigment. These findings provide insights into the evolution of this trait and the mechanisms underlying the convergence of this trait in two other plant species. This work contributes to our understanding of the mechanisms underlying the evolution of floral traits that are important for plant reproduction. This article is protected by copyright. The genetic structure of modern Europeans is strongly correlated with geography. However, the processes that shaped the genetic landscape of Europe during the intervening periods are not well understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from southern Germany dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. We also found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. Our results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. These results also suggest that bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. Our findings have implications for the development of vaccines and antiviral drugs against MERS-CoV and other bat coronaviruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic sequencing of undifferentiated febrile patients in Cambodia. This approach can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. Rapid public health response can be deployed to mitigate the impact of these diseases. The lagging strand of eukaryotic DNA replication is synthesized in short fragments called Okazaki fragments. The template for these fragments is the newly synthesized single-stranded DNA strand that is produced by DNA polymerases. The template for the lagging strand is the old DNA strand. The old DNA strand is protected from the action of DNA polymerases by the sliding clamp, proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). We show that the sliding clamp is not required for lagging strand synthesis. This discovery has profound implications for the mechanism of lagging strand synthesis. It also has implications for the role of the sliding clamp in other processes. For example, the sliding clamp is required for DNA synthesis in vitro. However, we show that the sliding clamp is not required for lagging strand synthesis in vitro. This suggests that the sliding clamp is not required for DNA synthesis in vivo.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, nucleic acids were the genetic material. In the laboratory, RNA can replicate itself, but it is unclear whether RNA can also be used to encode and express proteins. Here, we show that an RNA polymerase ribozyme can be evolved to improve its activity and generality, and that the improved polymerase can replicate RNA, amplify RNA templates, and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. These results suggest that RNA-based life may be more general than previously thought. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Urban change is a fundamental topic in urban studies. However, it is difficult to observe and measure. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic. The fungal pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus has evolved a mechanism to control copper toxicity. This study provides insight into the evolution of fungal metal homeostasis and the role of natural products in microbial interactions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is consistent with high formation temperatures. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals and the amorphous silica. The amorphous silica is derived from multiple aqueous solutions.

Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals. The geographic distribution of frost events is poorly understood, and the impact of frost on the performance of plants and animals is poorly understood. We use a large dataset of leaf-out dates and leaf-freezing temperatures to infer the frost resistance strategies of woody plants. We then use this information to forecast the vulnerability of forests to frost. Our results have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not well understood. The climate system is very complex. It is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of water vapor. We show that stratospheric water vapor plays an important role in the climate system. This is significant because the stratosphere is not well understood.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue. The color of some animals is determined by the presence of pigments. These animals are said to be “color blind.” The color of these animals is determined by the presence of a pigment called biliverdin. This discovery provides a mechanism for the evolution of green color in vertebrates. It also provides a mechanism for the evolution of green color in insects. Parchment is a material used for making books. It is made from animal skin. The source of parchment has been a long-standing controversy. This study uses a noninvasive method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the extraction of proteins from the parchment surface using a PVC eraser. The method is simple, objective, and noninvasive. The method can be used to identify the animal origin of parchment.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe mass extinction in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is still debated. The age model will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes. COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate the impact of COVID-19 on life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity. Our projections indicate that the Black−White life expectancy gap will increase by nearly 40%, and the Latino−White gap will decrease by more than 3 y. These projections have important implications for health policy and for the future of the US population.

Pressure is a powerful tool to induce chemical transformations. However, the chemical effects of pressure are not well understood. We show that pressure-induced metallization is accompanied by a decrease of electronegativity and chemical hardness. We also show that the pseudo–noble-gas configuration is a stable configuration under pressure. Our results have important implications for the understanding of the chemistry of the Earth’s interior and for the design of new materials.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its role in the climate system is poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography can reduce global fire activity, which in turn can reduce warming. This effect is most pronounced under lower emissions scenarios. However, the risk of more extreme fires is also higher. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to better understand the feedbacks between fire and climate. This can help to inform decisions about fire management and policy.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts through the strategic provision of a single glycan. This glycan is released by the host only at night, when the symbionts are most active. The catabolism of this glycan by the symbionts is also required for the acidification of the host’s crypts, which enhances the luminescence of the symbionts. Our results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general strategy used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microorganisms. Text data are ubiquitous. They are used to understand the world around us, to communicate, and to inform policy. However, text data are often unstructured, and it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and word embedding. We show how our method can be applied to a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method can be applied to any domain.

The Black Death, the deadliest epidemic in history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe. However, the climate conditions in Asia at the time of the first plague outbreaks are poorly understood. We show that the climate conditions in Asia were favorable for the survival of the plague bacterium for several years before the first plague outbreaks in Europe. We also show that the climate conditions in Europe were favorable for the survival of the bacterium for several years after the first plague outbreaks. These results suggest that the bacterium was repeatedly introduced into Europe, and that the disease was able to establish itself in Europe despite the climate conditions in Europe. This suggests that Europe was not a permanent reservoir for the bacterium. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web. They are also a critical prey species for many marine predators. In the Northeast Pacific, asteroids have recently experienced a mass mortality event. We show that the disease is caused by a virus. We also show that the virus is present in the environment and in the tissues of the asteroids. This suggests that the virus is spreading and that it is a threat to the ecosystem.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor prognosis. The IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects. We also show that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Finally, we generated an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other cancers. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean. It is the only island in the world that is both a biodiversity hotspot and a place where two continents met. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestry. The recent settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher contribution of males from Southeast Asia. In addition, we find that Madagascar is a young population, with a strong influence of geography on the present genomic diversity. These results help to understand the settlement history of Madagascar. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. Some of these RNAs encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases the activity of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. We also show that the RNA base pairs with two genes and that the base pairing and protein functions compete. This work provides insight into the evolution of dual-function RNAs and the mechanisms of RNA–protein competition. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains a challenge to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm to enhance antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers. They provide information on crop status, which is critical for farmers to make decisions on crop management. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective. We show that this information can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used for quantitative analysis. We show that this transformation can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show the potential of harnessing the power of the “people as sensors” network. This approach can be extended to other agricultural commodities and countries.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that requires the integration of information over time. The neural mechanisms underlying this ability are not well understood. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the human brain. Our model is based on the idea that memory is supported by changes in the excitability of individual neurons. These changes are adaptive and can be used to store information. We show that this mechanism can support memory on different timescales. We demonstrate that it can be used to bind information over time and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It may also have implications for other domains of cognitive science.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types. Our results demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the evolution of life on Earth. It is also one of the most studied, but the molecular mechanisms underlying this transition remain elusive. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings have important implications for the study of the molecular evolution of plastids and for the understanding of the origin of parasitic lifestyles. This article is protected by copyright. The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was caused by a combination of natural variability and anthropogenic climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the drought by a factor of five to six. This increase is expected to continue in the future. Our results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This is important for the design of drought risk management strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion is a remarkable coincidence. The discovery of quasicrystals in the red trinitite, the oldest known anthropogenic material, is even more remarkable. The discovery of quasicrystals in the red trinitite demonstrates that quasicrystals can be formed under extreme conditions and that the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems is a continuous process. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biosynthesis of chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in chlorophyll biosynthesis, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the diiron enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. These data delineate three classes of diiron cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Neuroinflammation is a hallmark of multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease. ASK1-deficient microglia/macrophages ameliorated the disease severity in EAE. ASK1-deficient astrocytes also reduced disease severity. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of disease. These findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes may be promising therapeutic targets for reducing neuroinflammation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades. In addition, the probability that precipitation deficits are also warm has increased. These findings suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions. This is important because the probability of warm–dry conditions is increasing in the future. Thus, anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of drought. This is a key finding for water managers, policy makers, and the public.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and a target for drug development. News media are a critical source of information for the public. However, the content of news coverage can have important consequences for the public’s understanding of the world. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent study of the effects of real news content on physiological reactions. Results show that people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. This negativity bias may have important implications for the content of news coverage.

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) channel is essential for a variety of cellular functions. In this study, we identify mutations in the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 and pore-forming protein ORAI1 that lead to dysregulated Ca2+ signaling. Our results suggest that the Ca2+ channel can be both activated and suppressed by mutations in the same protein. This may be a general principle in the regulation of the Ca2+ channel. Furthermore, we show that the Ca2+ channel can be inactivated by a slow process, which is suppressed by mutations in the channel. This may be a general principle in the regulation of the Ca2+ channel. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and form insoluble deposits that can spread throughout the brain. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we show that the spreading of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous. We also show that the spreading of aggregates is dependent on endocytosis and that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutics for neurodegenerative diseases. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The immune system is a critical factor in the maintenance of health and the prevention of disease. However, the immune system can also be a double-edged sword, as it can be exploited by pathogens to cause disease. The immune system is also a complex system that is constantly changing and adapting to the environment. This study provides a deeper understanding of the immune system and its role in the maintenance of health and the prevention of disease. It also provides insight into the role of the immune system in the pathogenesis of disease. This study has implications for the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a metabolic disease. Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are essential for cell growth. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that this inhibitor is effective in B-cell lines, but paradoxically increases cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease. The disease is caused by mutations in multiple genes, and the underlying molecular mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins. Rather, they are a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, but upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis, they aggregate. This observation suggests that the molecular mechanisms of ALS are more complex than previously thought. It also provides a potential target for therapeutic intervention. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal system is predicted to produce exotic quantum phenomena, including suppressed spontaneous emission, atom–light interaction anisotropy, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions. The system can be fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process. The system can be deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work is expected to advance the field of neutral atom physics and photonic crystal devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of angiosperms is a major evolutionary event. The earliest angiosperms are poorly understood. Montsechia is a plant that was first described more than 100 y ago. It is a plant that was poorly understood in the past. Now, based upon the study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens, a detailed analysis of Montsechia is presented. Montsechia is an aquatic angiosperm that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, a plant that is similar to Montsechia in morphology and reproduction. Montsechia opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution. This may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Parvoviruses are a group of small DNA viruses that cause a variety of diseases in humans. The evolution of parvoviruses has been studied using genetic sequences from recent years. However, the evolution of parvoviruses is poorly understood because of the lack of ancient viral sequences. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus B19 (B19V) sequences from humans who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also find that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level is rising, and it is rising quickly. This is well known. But the rate of sea level rise is not constant. It is accelerating. This is also well known. But the acceleration of sea level rise is not constant. It is accelerating even more quickly. This is not well known. We show that the acceleration of sea level rise is not a recent phenomenon. It has been accelerating for at least the last 25 y. This acceleration is driven by the thermal expansion of the oceans.

Pain is a normal part of life. As we age, we expect pain to increase. However, in America today, the elderly report less pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that pain is not increasing with age in America today. Instead, pain is increasing with age in midlife. This is not a good thing. Tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a key component of the mechanistic picture of enzyme catalysis. However, the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is difficult to obtain by crystallography. NMR-assisted crystallography is a method that uses solid-state NMR spectroscopy to characterize the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This structure provides insight into the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. The structure also provides insight into why the substrate indole reacts, but not benzimidazole. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide insight into the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates. This article is protected by copyright. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes a high mortality rate. There is no specific antiviral treatment available. Remdesivir is a nucleotide analog that inhibits viral replication. Here, we show that remdesivir is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This opens the possibility of remdesivir as a treatment for MERS-CoV and other coronaviruses. Remdesivir may also be considered for a wider range of viruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This may be of particular importance in the context of the ongoing outbreak. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.
