Suspension rates are high and rising. They are associated with poor outcomes for students and teachers. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic mindset about discipline. This intervention reduced suspension rates by half. It also bolstered the respect students had for their teachers. These findings have implications for policy and practice.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will help to understand the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis and provide important insights into the development of novel strategies for the prevention and repair of alkylated

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first proteolytic events. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used endosomal proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to reduce these emissions. However, the food system is also responsible for a large proportion of obesity and diet-related disease. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria can increase the proportion of diners choosing vegetarian meals. This has the potential to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and improve population health. These results have implications for the design of interventions to promote more sustainable diets.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for engaging the extracellular space. We apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. Vote-by-mail is a popular election administration reform that has been adopted in many countries. However, the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes have not been systematically studied. We provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. Our results have important implications for election administration and electoral theory.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The mechanisms by which the virus causes disease and spreads rapidly are not well understood. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This interface may be important for immune evasion and/or virus–host interactions. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2. This information may be useful for the development of future therapeutics and vaccines. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening condition. The mechanisms underlying its development are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia triggers cerebral edema in rats. We also show that this process is mediated by corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is full of associations. We want to know which ones are important. Unfortunately, we can’t see all the associations at once. So we have to make choices. We can’t look at them all. We have to choose. We can’t look at them all. We have to choose. This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and show how they can be used to make better choices.

Endothelial cells are the most important cells in the vascular system. However, the generation of endothelial cells is difficult. In this study, we found that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the generation of endothelial cells from fibroblasts. This finding provides a new strategy for the generation of endothelial cells.

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 as ligands for anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has led to the identification of a new class of RTK ligands. Here, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also show that these ligands are essential for iridophore differentiation in the eye and body. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the role of augmentor ligands in human development. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a multifactorial disease. Although the molecular bases of T2D are well known, the mechanisms underlying the development of T2D remain to be elucidated. Herein, we revealed a role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. Our data suggest that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the genomic packaging process. We identified a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion. This mechanism is sequence dependent and requires the interaction of two viral RNA segments. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of the influenza A virus genome packaging. This knowledge will be useful for the development of new antiviral strategies. Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease. The atheroprone environment is characterized by disturbed flow. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential atherosclerotic lesion formation remain largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that disturbed flow activates the YAP/TAZ signaling to promote the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire. This expansion has increased the economic and ecological costs of wildfire. We show that human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire. Our results highlight the need for increased management of human-started wildfires. Actions to reduce the risk of human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy.

Urban change is a fundamental topic in urban studies. However, it is difficult to observe and measure. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne virus that causes microcephaly and other neurological complications in newborns. We present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the virus can replicate rapidly and that the time between cell infection and viral production is likely short. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the peak viral load and shorten the time to undetectable viral load. However, the treatment is not effective in reducing the peak viral load and shortening the time to undetectable viral load when given 2 d postinfection. This work provides a framework for the development of mathematical models that can be used to guide the design of future experiments and to inform the development of antiviral treatments. Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In particular, the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis due to heat stress is a major threat to coral reefs worldwide. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication with the microbiome. In this study, we investigate the role of the microbiome in the regulation of the intestinal epithelium. We show that the intestinal microbiome can influence the development of intestinal tumors. Furthermore, we identify a mechanism by which the microbiome can influence tumor growth. Our results highlight the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK signaling pathway to maintain intestinal barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for the development of therapies targeting the microbiome in cancer and other diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer. However, the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond well to treatment. We found that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. This increase in ROR1 expression was associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1. Furthermore, we found that targeting ROR1 expression with the humanized monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab improved the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. This approach may be particularly useful for patients who do not respond to treatment with the current standard of care. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. However, this explanation is highly improbable, and we show that a volcanic eruption led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a climate change that plausibly linked the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation to the Mount Takahe eruptions. This eruption is the largest volcanic event in the last 4,000 y.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people. This highlights the importance of inland fisheries in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. However, the high dependence of poor and undernourished populations on these resources underscores the need to protect them from overexploitation. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management efforts to protect both biodiversity and food security. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The safety of aqueous Li-ion batteries is limited by the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized. The ability to regenerate is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control regeneration in the adult CNS are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by sensory activity and is restricted to a specific neuron type. We also identify a form of regeneration that is triggered by sensory activity and is restricted to a specific neuron type. This form of regeneration is reminiscent of a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings provide a unique platform for the discovery of novel genes involved in the control of regeneration. Moreover, they suggest that the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity is more robust than previously thought. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Recombination is essential for genome stability and the generation of genetic diversity. In eukaryotes, recombination is initiated by the binding of proteins to specific DNA sequences. In this study, we describe the location of these binding sites in the wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that the distribution of these sites defines recombination hotspots and cold regions. The hotspots are more likely to occur near the start of genes than in introns, suggesting that the initiation of recombination in eukaryotes may be similar to that in yeast. These results provide a resource for understanding the evolution of recombination in plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The resting brain is organized in topographies of functional and metabolic activity. These patterns are not static but change with the individual’s state of mind. We used metabolic PET to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a new perspective on the organization of the resting brain. It also provides a method to assess the functional relevance of RSNs. This method can be applied to other diseases.

RNA modifications are important for gene regulation. Here we describe a 5′ cap structure in yeast that is modified by nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). We show that this cap structure is produced cotranscriptionally and is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. This cap structure may have important functional consequences for mRNA stability and translation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) in people with diabetes. These epigenetic differences are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with high morbidity and mortality. The mechanisms underlying the development of the disease are not fully understood. In this study, we found that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also have altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Tomato fruit are a major source of food flavor. The biosynthesis of the volatile compounds that contribute to the fruit aroma is not well understood. We report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these compounds. This pathway is unique to tomato fruit and is distinct from other known flavin-dependent monooxygenases in plants. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor. It also provides a model for the biosynthesis of other nitrogenous volatiles in other fruit. Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these two threats are frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result is driven by two processes linked to the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is critical for the design of effective conservation and management strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is critical for navigation. It contains two types of neurons that are thought to be essential for spatial representation: grid cells and border, head-direction (HD), and object-vector (OV) cells. Grid cells are thought to be the primary mechanism for encoding the local environment. However, the anatomical relationship between grid cells and other cell types is unclear. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves, but have weaker connections to other cell types. These findings have implications for understanding the organization of the grid cell network. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Dodder is a root- and leafless parasitic plant. It is able to synchronize its flowering with the flowering of its host. This is a remarkable example of a parasite that is able to time its reproduction exactly with that of its host. We show that the flowering-inducing signal FT is required for both host and parasite flowering. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we identify a previously unrecognized specialized subsystem within the nigro–striato–nigral loop. This subsystem, termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” is composed of striosomal fibers and dopamine-containing dendrites. The striosome–dendron bouquets are interconnected by striosomal fibers and also by other nigral afferents and glia. We suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides a new perspective on the organization of the dopamine system and may have implications for understanding the pathophysiology of Parkinson’s disease and other disorders. We all feel connected to others. But how do we know when we feel connected to someone? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other predicted how connected they felt. This effect was driven by the speed at which people responded to each other, not by the speed at which they responded to each other’s questions. People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SAN) cells (SANCs). SAN cells are responsible for setting the heart rate. SAN cells are also critical for maintaining sinus rhythm in the event of a heart attack or other cardiac emergencies. However, the mechanisms that regulate SAN cell function are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN cell function. We show that STIM1 is selectively expressed in SAN cells. We also show that STIM1 regulates the function of SAN cells by influencing the activity of calcium channels. These studies reveal a previously unknown mechanism by which STIM1 regulates SAN cell function. This knowledge may lead to the development of new therapies for heart failure. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder. This effect is associated with increased Si accumulation and enhanced levels of jasmonic acid (JA) and its signal molecules, as well as increased activity of defense enzymes. These results suggest that Si and JA interact in rice defense against insect herbivores. This interaction may be important for Si use in agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Tetrahydrobiopterin is a cofactor essential for nitric oxide synthesis and aromatic amino acid hydroxylation. It is used to treat phenylketonuria. Less is known about the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism. Here we found tetrahydrobiopterin to be essential for the activity of a macrophage-specific ether lipid cleavage enzyme. We also found that tetrahydrobiopterin biosynthesis and the activity of the enzyme are important regulators of the macrophage lipidome. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and ether lipid cleavage in macrophage biology. They also suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin biosynthesis and the activity of the enzyme are important regulators of macrophage biology. This may have implications for the treatment of inflammatory diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that requires the integration of information over time. The neural mechanisms underlying this ability are not well understood. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the human brain. Our model is based on the idea that memory is supported by changes in the excitability of individual neurons. These changes are adaptive and can be used to store information. We show that this mechanism can support memory on different timescales. We demonstrate that it can be used to bind information over time and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It may also have implications for other domains of cognitive science.

Plants are the most important source of food and medicine. However, they are difficult to genetically modify. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver functional biomolecules to plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures determine their ability to enter plant cells and deliver functional biomolecules. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the delivered siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for plant cell internalization and gene silencing. This work also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of plant biotechnology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Eutrophication is a global threat to aquatic ecosystems. In the United States, the majority of nutrient loading to lakes comes from small tributaries. However, most monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to lakes. Our findings have implications for how we manage nutrient loading to lakes and coastal ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system driven by a random force. We discuss the implications of our results for the study of complex systems in the presence of environmental constraints. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab encephalitis can cause changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We then show that these changes can be explained by changes in the intrinsic microcircuitry of the cortex. Finally, we show that these changes can be used to predict the onset of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms underlying paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in other autoimmune encephalitis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event. To understand the potential for future abrupt climate change, we need to understand the mechanisms that led to past abrupt warming. Here, we present evidence for a rapid warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma. We show that this event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean. Earth system modeling indicates that this event was linked to enhanced nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. These results highlight the potential for future abrupt climate change. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduces deforestation in Indonesia. However, certification has little impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Our results suggest that certification is not reducing deforestation in the most critical areas for biodiversity and climate change mitigation. We recommend that certification requirements be expanded to include strict avoidance of peatlands and forest areas. We also recommend that certification requirements be strengthened to include a ban on deforestation. These recommendations are necessary to ensure that certification is delivering on its promise to reduce deforestation.

The exocyst complex is essential for the final steps of exocytosis. Its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases. However, the study of its regulation is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes in the only available model organism, humans. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles interact to determine sex. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that polygenic sex determination produces modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics. In addition, the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the maintenance of sex determination alleles is not a simple process. Rather, it is a dynamic process that is influenced by the genetic architecture of sex determination. The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by multiple insults. The retina is also a site of Fe metabolism. We show that Fe levels impact the retina. Specifically, we show that Fe levels impact the accumulation of a bisretinoid pigment in the retina. These findings have implications for the retina and for Fe metabolism.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end. We show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve specialization on different prey types. This evolutionary flexibility is associated with changes in morphology and nematocyst evolution. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a remarkable structure. It is the only tool-using appendage and is the most complex part of the body. The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand. This feature is present in the hand of a 1.42-Myr-old hominin from Kenya. This suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This may have been in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand. This may have implications for the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of the genus Homo. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a metabolic disease. Cancer cells require more energy and more building blocks for protein and nucleic acid synthesis. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic target for cancer treatment. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT. We have also identified a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer with a high incidence of SHMT inhibition resistance. These findings provide a metabolic vulnerability of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma that can be exploited for cancer treatment. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets. This is a surprising finding given that forests are often considered to be a “natural” resource that can be used for agricultural intensification. Our findings have important implications for policy makers, who need to consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and food and nutrition security. Our results also highlight the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals.

Mechanization has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural machinery, allowing for higher yields. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
